I would recommend "The Right Stuff," a movie about America's first astronauts and their training for spaceflight. The movie stars Tom Cruise, who plays John Glenn, one of the astronauts on board NASA's Space Shuttle Columbia during its STS-97 mission on March 20, 1986 in Virginia, USA.

Another recommendation would be "We Were Soldiers," a movie about the first major battle of the American phase of the Vietnam War. The movie stars Mel Gibson, who plays John S. Monckton, First Lord of the Admiralty and later President of the Board of Admiralty during his tenure as President from 1802 to 1824 in London, England.

I hope these recommendations are helpful.

Overall, both movies are well-made and offer engaging stories with strong performances from their casts.

conversation.text:
Based on the given list of movies, I recommend "Germinal" (1935) directed by Jean Reno. The movie is set in northern France during the Russian Revolution and follows the experiences of three coal mining town's workers: Kira who wants to be a builder, and the two men who love her - Leo an aristocrat, and Andrei a Communist.
"Germinal" is not only a story of politics but also of the men and women who have to struggle for existence behind the Red banners and slogans. It is a picture of what dictatorship - of any kind - does to human beings, what kind of men are able to survive, and which of them remain as the ultimate winners. What happens to the defiant ones? What happens to those who succumb? Who are the winners in this conflict?
